body:
Oh interesting we have the same problem while using runit with chef. This is clearly beyond my field of competency. The solution on our side was to `pkill gunicorn` when the process gets stopped which is not clean but got us this far...

I'm open to trying `os.exec` or anything that will clean subprocesses!
Interesting indeed we also saw that behavior. I can prepare a PR

I noticed a year or so ago that CTRL-C had a different effect then our process manager was using. CTRL-C was killing the sub processes but `sudo sv stop airflow_service` didn't. I looked a bit into the different signals (SIGTERM, SIGINT, ..) and the Python signal module but didn't figure it out in a half day or so and got frustrated, resorted to an os level approach featuring `pkill`. 

I'd love for someone to figure this out.

Ok the issue is that gunicorn forks. This way signals (ie. SIGKILL) are not being passed to the children. Thus you need a way to track the PID of the process group of the children. `os.exec` is not the right way to do this as it is deprecated. However, normally you can solve this by passing `os.preexec_fn=os.setsid` to `subprocess.Popen` but this only works when executing as root as it breaks some assumed requirements. There are two solutions to this:
1. Let airflow run gunicorn, store its PID in a file (ie. /var/run/airflow-webserver.pid) and exit immediately. This how most daemons are run and init.d scripts and systemd know how to handle this. However it might break some assumptions around airflow how it is currently run.
2. Create a signal handler in airflow that manages the gunicorn process and passes the signals. This is more complex but keeps the way airflow currently works.

I'm in favor of option 1 as it is more standard, I'll see if I can keep current behavior by including a flag (-f for foreground or something like that). Please let me know if option 2 seems more logical.
@ybendana can you please test the PR?
@mistercrunch I am slightly worried that some other subprocess might also need some work (celery workers?). I didn't check though.

@mistercrunch I'm not sure if I agree with you. The super_user functionality is exposed within airflow so this change makes that configurable from ldap. My initial implementation for ldap made everyone superuser which in the end is not something you want I guess.

However, on the whole I like a a role based access better (with flask-principal), instead of piggybacking some authorization on top of the authentication (which in general you should not do). This would allow a more flexible approach, eg. authentication in ldap, authorization in db).
@asnir I would go for some kind of storage outside of the Docker container, like HDFS or S3.

When we deploy new DAGs, we restart both the airflow scheduler and webserver in order to reload the DAG bags in those processes. We use local executor at Agari. Our deployment automation (Capistrano) script takes care of both DAG deployment and the restart post-DAG deployment.

```
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sqlalchemy/orm/query.py", line 2634, in first

  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sqlalchemy/orm/session.py", line 214, in _assert_active

InvalidRequestError: This Session's transaction has been rolled back due to a previous exception during flush. To begin a new transaction with this Session, first issue Session.rollback(). Original exception was: (pickle.PicklingError) Can't pickle <class 'celery.utils.log.ProcessAwareLogger'>: it's not found as celery.utils.log.ProcessAwareLogger [SQL: u'INSERT INTO dag_pickle (pickle, created_dttm, pickle_hash) VALUES (%(pickle)s, now(), %(pickle_hash)s) RETURNING dag_pickle.id'] [parameters: [{'pickle_hash': -1909267389068563253, 'pickle': <DAG: check_users>}]]
```

ProcessAwareLogger defined  in celery.utils.log inside function and can not be created during unpickling. Airflow does not handle this error correctly (rollback should be explicitly called) and scheduler db session becomes unusable. 

Disabling pickle just works

Hey @mistercrunch, thanks for the feedback !

Indeed, computing time can become a barrier for quick fixes, and it's only expected to grow as people add more dag tests.

We also agree that it would be difficult to run several tests in parallel as each test configures airflow with a specific dag folder and each test uses the same database (e.g. we at least know that they share the same Variables to parametrize the dags).

We've identified several possibilities :
1. Paralellize the dag tests on existing builds:
   - Run the unit tests on the full build matrix, for each PR
   - Spread the dag tests on existing builds to "parallelize" them, for each PR
     (e.g. backfill tests on one build, scheduler tests on another)
   
   => Simple but only pushes the problem a bit further as people will add more tests
2. Trigger dag tests nightly through the travis api:
   - Run the unit tests on the full build matrix, for each PR
   - Run the dag tests on the full build matrix, nightly, triggered through the [travis api](https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/triggering-builds)
   
   => Requires external service that triggers travis every night
   => Some bugs might be caught after being merged to master (although before going into `airbnb_prod`)
3. Trigger dag tests through a staging branch mechanism:
   - Create a staging branch that acts as the trunk, keep master for validated changes through dag tests
   - Run the unit tests on the full build matrix for each PR on trunk
   - Run the dag tests on the full build matrix, for each PR on master
   
   => Heavily complexifies the process with extra PRs

We think the second option makes more sense, as it doesn't slow down the PRs while still protecting the `airbnb_prod` with dags tests (or integration tests).

I you agree, we only need to update the travis configuration and find that extra service to trigger the nightly builds. Would you have a way of automating the travis trigger nightly from inside airbnb ? Through airflow ? ;D

So running a `trigger_dag` with an `execution_date` parameter would be what I am looking for, but solution may not be straightforward because tasks within a DAG can have different `start_dates` and `schedule_intervals` (not sure about the latter).

Thanks for the PR, hey actually recently I realized that you can also just print the engine and that sqlalchemy does that for you when it stringifies the object.

```
from sqlalchemy import create_engine
create_engine('mysql://hello:secret@localhost').url

Out: mysql://hello:***@localhost
```

It's by design, if a "running" DagRun was created it would create a race condition between say a local backfill and the scheduler. DagRun are mostly designed to inform the scheduler as to where to evaluate and trigger tasks as part of normal operations (schedule and filling reprocessing small chunks using `clear`).

A DAG can't have multiple `schedule_intervals` as it is a DAG level parameter.

For context, we have this exact problem with one of our production tasks. We have a `PythonOperator` with a 4 hour timeout that spins up several background threads to do a bunch of work. Rarely, the task will just hang forever without triggering a timeout. It could either be an uncaught exception happening on one of the background threads, or the task is just taking really long and never finishing for some reason.

I'm trying to understand the guarantees that airflow's scheduler is able to provide regarding multithreading with `PythonOperators`.
Not on the Airbnb side as far as I can tell.
I was looking at this today and confirmed the issue was only appearing when we had a pool defined. Thanks for the fix!

I think that's more of a Python question than an Airflow question and that's beyond me to be honest. Maybe reading the code of the timeout context manager might help:
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/utils.py#L607

I also noticed that the logs got more verbose recently. I'm still somewhat challenged when trying to figure out proper logging best practices in Python. Allowing external modules to import Airflow and set logging level for it specifically is important. It seems like to do this we need to associate all airflow logging to `logging.getLogger('airflow')` ?

I think in both cases of threads and child processes you will need to explicitly handle both:
a) exceptions raised in the remove thread/process
b) terminating (or somehow handling) the child thread/process when a timeout occurs in the parent, presumably with code passed to on_failure_callback.

For more depth, check out this discussion on SO about handling exceptions raised in threads.
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2829329/catch-a-threads-exception-in-the-caller-thread-in-python

Maxime, 

Shouldn't we simply deprecate Python 2.6 ?

The documentation as it stands states:

> Note that Airflow is only tested under Python 2.7.\* as many of our dependencies don’t support python3 (as of 2015-06).

A perhaps more direct comment would be the software requires Python 2.7.\* and has experimental support for Python 3. Python 2.6 present in systems like RHEL6 and derivatives is not supported.

Otherwise we will be expecting users to quickly find: https://groups.google.com/d/msg/airbnb_airflow/eOW-JV9HKXs/EE4KRbq2CgAJ

Python 3 is supported as far as I can tell, some operators that have 2.7 dependencies won't work though.

It doesn't sound like Airflow is the right solution for a few reasons. For one, you don't want to execute on a fixed schedule. You essentially want to be notified when new data arrives -- when it does, you want to execute a transformation to hive.

If you were using AWS, I'd recommend that you drop your csv files to S3. You can set S3 up to publish new object notifications via SNS/SQS. You can then write a SQS consumer to read the SQS notifications, pull the csv objects out of S3, transform it, and then insert it into Hive. 

This is a continuous process.. and does not rely on a schedule. It's okay to have some ad-hoc DAGs and tasks in airflow that are not tied to a schedule, but often they will be triggered by some other job that is running on a schedule.

The documentation recommends `logging.getLogger(__name__)`:

> The logger name hierarchy is analogous to the Python package hierarchy, and identical to it if you organise your loggers on a per-module basis using the recommended construction `logging.getLogger(__name__)`. That’s because in a module, `__name__` is the module’s name in the Python package namespace.

https://docs.python.org/2/library/logging.html

If there is no objection, we will create a PR :grin:

It seems reasonable, someone contributed a LoggingMixin class that we use in many places and it must follow the module namespace approach `+ '.' + classname`. It seems like it fits the model described with an extra level of detail. There must be a fair amount of orphan logging calls though. I'm happy reviewing PRs that move the needle in the right direction. 

https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/5afe1d16f0b9930309fab2c912a33e2c3b16c250/airflow/utils.py#L765
